ive tones and then awaiting and hopefully recording=A0morse code responses?=

I'm going to have to run this one past my father, being h=
e is a Ham 
Operator (KA2RHU) in NJ for anyone who wants to know. I took 5 =
files 
and played them in a sequence and recorded it, it consists of tone 
=
frequencies ranging from 100hz, 250hz, 440hz, 1khz and 10khz. They 
were 5 =
second clips of each and than i ran it through EvpMaker and it 
sounds like=
 morse code, but i have to brush up on it to see if it makes 
any sense. Is=
 it possible for them to communicate through morse code? 
I've attached a 3=
0 second clip of the example running it through 
EvpMaker. I'll also attach=
 my original tone file i created.

-Steve H.

<html><head><style type="text/css"><!-- DIV {margin:0px;} --></style></head><body><div style="font-family:times new roman, new york, times, serif;font-size:12pt"><DIV style="FONT-SIZE: 12pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman, new york, times, serif">Hi steve   Not sure about the concept.  Will you be playing the five tones and then awaiting and hopefully recording morse code responses?  Or will you be sending out a question in morse code and listening for a morse code answer?  With the great success rate some of you have I think you could yodel and get something back...maybe morse code will work.  Yodelling...now there's and idea.   lol   Ron<BR><BR>

<P><BR><BR>I'm going to have to run this one past my father, being he is a Ham <BR>Operator (KA2RHU) in NJ for anyone who wants to know. They <BR>were 5 second clips of each and than i ran it through EvpMaker and it <BR>sounds like morse code, but i have to brush up on it to see if it makes <BR>any sense. Is it possible for them to communicate through morse code? <BR>I've attached a 30 second clip of the example running it through <BR>EvpMaker.
